name: Limassol
fun_fact: Fun fact: Halloumi cheese has been made in Cyprus since Byzantine times (mid-16th century) from a mixture of goat and sheep milk. It's the only cheese in the world that can be grilled or fried without melting, earning it the title of Cyprus's national cheese and a protected designation of origin.

hero_dishes.name: Meze (Cypriot Feast)
hero_dishes.description: An elaborate culinary marathon of 20-30 small dishes served in progression: cold appetizers/salads, hot dishes like grilled halloumi, culminating in charcoal-grilled meats or fresh seafood
hero_dishes.origin_story: Ancient roots in the Eastern Mediterranean. In Cyprus, meze became a ritual of hospitality - offering dozens of small plates as a gesture of abundance. The meal structure is sacred: olives, tahini, hummus, tzatziki with bread, then hot dishes, ending with grilled meats.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Meze Taverna Restaurant (Old Town) - family-run for 20+ years, outstanding fish meze, always full so book ahead; Karatello Tavern (Lanitis Carob Mill) - generous portions in rustic converted warehouse; Syrian Restaurant - Lebanese/Syrian twist with tables under vine leaves and grapes

hero_dishes.name: Halloumi (Grilled or Fried)
hero_dishes.description: Semi-hard white-brined cheese with elastic texture made from goat and sheep milk, served grilled with char marks or fried until golden
hero_dishes.origin_story: Dating back to Byzantine times, halloumi has captured food lovers worldwide. Its unique high melting point means it can be grilled or fried - something no other cheese can do. It's Cyprus's most famous culinary export.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Every taverna in Limassol; Taverna Forsos (Mouttagiaka) - don't miss their halloumi in the garden courtyard; Taverna Yialousa (Mouttagiaka) - cheese-stuffed pasta (halloumi ravioli)

hero_dishes.name: Sheftalia
hero_dishes.description: Small cylindrical sausages made with minced pork or lamb, onions, parsley, and spices, wrapped in caul fat that melts during grilling
hero_dishes.origin_story: Traditional Cypriot kebabs without skin - the caul fat forms the sausage casing and melts away on the grill, creating incredible flavor. A staple of meze and often enjoyed in warm pita bread.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Taverna Forsos (Mouttagiaka) - weekend dinners with locals in a leafy courtyard; Karatello Tavern - part of their generous meze spreads

hero_dishes.name: Loukoumades
hero_dishes.description: Deep-fried honey puffs, crispy on outside and fluffy inside, drizzled with honey and sometimes cinnamon
hero_dishes.origin_story: Ancient Greek origin, but in Limassol they're especially popular during Carnival when street vendors sell them fresh to revellers. The perfect sweet ending to a meze feast.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Taverna Forsos - locals rave about them; street vendors throughout Old Town during festivals

signature_drinks.name: Cyprus Brandy
signature_drinks.description: Locally produced brandy made by Limassol-based distilleries since 1871
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: After dinner as a digestif, often offered as a gesture of hospitality at traditional tavernas. Limassol is the heart of Cyprus brandy production.

signature_drinks.name: Zivania
signature_drinks.description: Strong distilled spirit made from grape pomace, Cyprus's traditional firewater
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Served in small glasses, often at the end of a long meze meal. Locals treat it with respect - it's potent!
